facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 57 of 1957 and Criminal Misc. Petition No. 294 of 1957 filed.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 57 of 1957 and Criminal Misc. Petition No. 294 of 1957.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated September 28, 1956 of former Andhra High Court at Guntur in Criminal Revision Case No. 241 of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated September 28, 1956, of the former Andhra High Court at Guntur in Criminal Revision Case No. 241 of 1956.

facts.text: 26 appellants committed to Court of Session, Guntur Division for trial under ss. 147, 148, 323, 324, 302 r/w 34, 149 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: The 26 appellants have been committed to the Court of Session, Guntur Division, to take their trial for offences punishable under ss. 147, 148, 323, 324 and 302, read with ss. 34 and 149, Indian Penal Code.

facts.text: State of Andhra Pradesh impleaded as sole respondent.

anchor.surface_text: They impleaded the State of Andhra Pradesh as the sole respondent.

facts.text: Union of India allowed to intervene.

anchor.surface_text: The Union of India has been allowed to intervene on an application made in that behalf in view of the fact that the provisions of the Central Act have been impugned as unconstitutional.

facts.text: Local police took cognizance of rioting with murder on December 22, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: The local police took cognizance of a serious occurrence of rioting with murder on December 22, 1955.

facts.text: Police investigated the case and submitted charge-sheet under IPC sections to magistrate.

anchor.surface_text: The local police investigated the case, and after recording such evidence as it could collect in respect of the occurrence, submitted a charge-sheet under the aforesaid sections of the Indian Penal Code, to the magistrate having jurisdiction to entertain the case.

facts.text: Magistrate committed accused under s. 207A CrPC.

anchor.surface_text: The magistrate, following the procedure laid down in s. 207A of the Code committed the persons shown in the charge-sheet as the accused persons, to take their trial before the Court of Session.

facts.text: Accused filed revision applications under ss. 435 and 439 CrPC to High Court to quash commitment order.

anchor.surface_text: A number of applications in revision, under ss. 435 and 439 of the Code, were made on behalf of the accused persons, to the High Court of Andhra Pradesh, to quash the order of commitment, chiefly on the ground that the said order having been passed under the provisions of s. 207A of the Code  was void,

facts.text: High Court dismissed revisions holding ss. 207, 207A constitutional.

anchor.surface_text: The revisional applications were heard by Krishna Rao J. who dismissed them, holding that the provisions impugned were not unconstitutional and that, therefore, the order of commitment was valid in law.

facts.text: High Court granted certificate under Art. 134(1)(c) Constitution for appeal to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants applied for and obtained the necessary certificate under Art. 134 1  c  of the Constitution that the case was a fit one for appeal to this Court.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by SINHA J. on September 17, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: 1957. September 17. The following Judgment of the Court was delivered by SINHA J.-

facts.text: Appellants challenge constitutionality of ss. 207 and 207A CrPC introduced by Act XXVI of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: The only question that arises for determination in this appeal on a certificate granted by the High Court of Andhra Pradesh at Hyderabad, under Art. 134 1  c  of the Constitution, is the constitutionality of the provisions of ss. 207 and 207A,

facts.text: Sections 207 and 207A introduced by Act XXVI of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: Code of Criminal Procedure  hereinafter referred to as the Code , which, read together, were introduced into the Code by Act XXVI of 1955.

facts.text: Appellants argue s.207A procedure less advantageous to accused than other commitment procedures.

anchor.surface_text: The arguments addressed to the High Court have been repeated in this Court and are to the effect that ss. 207 and 207A, as they now stand, provide for two separate procedures in the committing court,

facts.text: Krishna Rao J. heard and dismissed revision petitions.

anchor.surface_text: The revisional applications were heard by Krishna Rao J. who dismissed them,

issues.text: The only question that arises for determination in this appeal [...] is the constitutionality of the provisions of ss. 207 and 207A, Code of Criminal Procedure

anchor.surface_text: The only question that arises for determination in this appeal on a certificate granted by the High Court of Andhra Pradesh at Hyderabad, under Art. 134 1  c  of the Constitution, is the constitutionality of the provisions of ss. 207 and 207A,

issues.text: we have to consider the question of the constitutionality of those provisions
whether or not there has been objectionable discrimination

whether the provisions of s. 207A of the Code was void, as those provisions were unconstitutional for the reason that they introduced discrimination as against accused persons in respect of whom a police charge-sheet had been submitted

anchor.surface_text: A number of applications in revision, under ss. 435 and 439 of the Code, were made on behalf of the accused persons, to the High Court of Andhra Pradesh, to quash the order of commitment, chiefly on the ground that the said order having

issues.text: whether ss. 207 and 207A, as they now stand, provide for two separate procedures in the committing court [...] which when examined in their details, show that the procedure in respect of a case instituted on a police report is less advantageous to the accused than the other procedure

anchor.surface_text: The arguments addressed to the High Court have been repeated in this Court and are to the effect that ss. 207 and 207A, as they now stand, provide for two separate procedures in the committing court, namely, (1) in respect of a case instituted

arguments.claim: The order of commitment passed under s. 207A is void as s. 207A provisions are unconstitutional because they introduce discrimination against accused persons where a police charge-sheet has been submitted.

anchor.surface_text: A number of applications in revision, under ss. 435 and 439 of the Code, were made on behalf of the accused persons, to the High Court of Andhra Pradesh, to quash the order of commitment, chiefly on the ground that the said order having been passed under the provisions of s. 207A of the Code  was void,

arguments.court_reasoning: Classification between police report cases and complaints is reasonable with intelligible differentia and rational nexus to speedy trial objective under Art. 14.

arguments.claim: ss. 207 and 207A provide for two separate procedures in committing court: one for police report cases under s. 207A less advantageous to accused than procedure under other provisions of Chapter XVIII for other cases.

anchor.surface_text: The arguments addressed to the High Court have been repeated in this Court and are to the effect that ss. 207 and 207A, as they now stand, provide for two separate procedures in the committing court, namely, (1) in respect of a case instituted

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ily speaking, as soon as information of the companymission of a companynizable offence has been laid before a police officer in-charge of a police sta

arguments.court_reasoning: Assumes differences exist but not always disadvantageous; changes aim to simplify and expedite.

arguments.claim: Under s. 208(3) accused can apply for process to compel witness attendance/production but s. 207A(2) speaks only of prosecution not accused.

anchor.surface_text: By way of illustration, it was urged that under s. 208 3 , it is open to an accused person to apply to the magistrate to issue process to compel the attendance of any witness or the production of any document, but sub-s.  2  of s. 207A,

arguments.claim: s. 207A(4) refers only to prosecution evidence whereas corresponding s. 208(1) refers to evidence for prosecution or accused.

anchor.surface_text: Again, it is pointed out that sub-s.  4  of s. 207A, makes reference only to the prosecution evidence, whereas the corresponding s. 208 1  makes reference to the evidence that may be produced in support of the prosecution or on behalf

arguments.claim: No provisions in s. 207A corresponding to s. 209(2) and s. 213(2) empowering magistrate to discharge accused.

anchor.surface_text: Similarly, it has been pointed out that there are no provisions in s. 207A corresponding to those of s. 209 2 , and s. 213 2 , empowering the magistrate to discharge the accused nor is there any provision in the impugned s. 207A

arguments.claim: No provision in s. 207A corresponding to s. 215 relating to quashing of commitments.

anchor.surface_text: nor is there any provision in the impugned s. 207A corresponding to s. 215 relating to quashing of commitments. Further, it was pointed out that whereas s. 209 1 contains the words no sufficient grounds

arguments.claim: s. 209(1) has 'no sufficient grounds' for commitment but s. 207A(6) has 'no grounds'.

anchor.surface_text: Further, it was pointed out that whereas s. 209 1 contains the words no sufficient grounds for committing the accused person, sub-s.  6  of s. 207A has the words nogrounds for committing the accused.

arguments.claim: New s. 207A procedure deprives accused of benefits under ss. 162 and 215 CrPC and ss. 27, 101-106, 114(g) Evidence Act.

anchor.surface_text: It has further been argued that in the new procedure adopted in the impugned s. 207A, the accused person has been deprived of the benefits under ss. 162 and 215 of the Code, and under ss. 27, 101 to 106 and 114-1ll.  g  of the Evidence Act.

The revisional applications were heard by Krishna Rao J. who dismissed them, holding that the provisions impugned were not unconstitutional and that, therefore, the order of commitment was valid in law.

arguments.court_reasoning: Supreme Court agrees after applying Art. 14 reasonable classification test.

arguments.claim: Differences in procedures exist but changes by Act XXVI of 1955 not always to disadvantage of accused; introduced to simplify and expedite commitment proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: We shall assume for the purpose of examining the constitutionality of the impugned provisions of the amended Code that there are differences in the two kinds of procedure envisaged in Chapter XVIII of the Code, relating to commitment proceedings,

arguments.qualifiers: we shall assume... by no means clear

arguments.claim: CrPC has always prescribed different procedures based on gravity of offences, court power, cognizable/non-cognizable, warrant/summons cases, etc.

anchor.surface_text: It is a well-known fact that the amending Act aforesaid introduced changes into the old Code with a view to simplifying and expediting procedure relating to trial of offences and to inquiries preceding such trials. It has also to be remembered

arguments.claim: In police investigated cases, prior inquiry by responsible public servant justifies summary commitment procedure for speedy justice.
Impugned provisions do not affect trial procedure which remains same; prior cases on trial changes irrelevant.
Classification between commitment on police report and on complaint satisfies Art. 14: intelligible differentia (prior public servant inquiry) and rational nexus (speedy trial).

holdings.text: The provisions of ss. 207 and 207A, Code of Criminal Procedure, introduced by Act XXVI of 1955, are constitutional and do not violate Article 14 of the Constitution.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Assumes procedural differences exist but justified by legislative policy of simplification and expedition; classification based on prior police investigation satisfies Article 14 reasonable classification test with intelligible differentia and rational nexus to speedy trial objective.

holdings.text: There has been no objectionable discrimination under Article 14 in the classification between commitment procedures for police report cases under s. 207A and complaint cases under other provisions.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Classification founded on intelligible differentia of prior inquiry by responsible public servant in police cases, with rational nexus to object of expeditious administration of justice and speedy trial, as per twin test from Budhan Choudhry v. State of Bihar.

holdings.text: The impugned provisions have not affected the procedure at the trial stage, which remains the same for both classes of cases.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes prior precedents on trial procedure changes as irrelevant since commitment inquiry differs but trial procedure unchanged.

holdings.text: Differences in commitment procedures under ss. 207, 207A and other provisions of Chapter XVIII exist but changes introduced by Act XXVI of 1955 are not by any means always to the disadvantage of the accused.

anchor.surface_text: We shall assume for the purpose of examining the constitutionality of the impugned provisions of the amended Code that there are differences in the two kinds of procedure envisaged in Chapter XVIII of the Code, relating to commitment proceedings,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Assumption for argument; legislative changes aimed at simplifying and expediting proceedings in cognizable offences investigated by police.

precedents.case_name: Budhan Choudhry v State of Bihar
precedents.cited_proposition: Article 14 forbids class legislation but does not forbid reasonable classification; classification must be founded on intelligible differentia with rational relation to object of statute
precedents.cited_holding: upheld constitutionality of section 30 of the Code against Art. 14 challenge

anchor.surface_text: Matajog Dobey v. H.C. Bhari 1 . In that case, the constitutionality of section 197 of the Code, was questioned. The contention raised in that case was that the section vested arbitrary power in the Government to grant or withhold sanction which could be withheld or granted at the sweet will of the Executive.

precedents.case_name: Matajog Dobey v H C Bhari

precedents.cited_holding: overruled contention that s.197 vests arbitrary discriminatory power
